TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Loamy-skeletal, mixed, superactive, frigid, shallow Aridic Haplustolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Casvare very gravelly loam-woodland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
Oe--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed organic material, chiefly needles, bark and twigs.
A1--0 to 3 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) very gravelly loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; moderate medium granular structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; 30 percent pebbles, 10 percent cobble, and 5 percent stones; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 8 inches thick)
A2--3 to 6 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) very gravelly sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; 45 percent pebbles; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); clear smooth boundary.  (0 to 6 inches thick)
AB--6 to 10 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) extremely gravelly sandy loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; 80 percent pebbles; slightly alkaline (pH 7.8); clear wavy boundary.  (0 to 5 inches thick)
Bk--10 to 17 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) extremely gravelly sandy loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; 40 percent rock structure; massive; soft, very friable, slightly sticky and nonplastic; 80 percent pebbles, 5 percent cobble; strongly effervescent, calcium carbonate coatings on rock fragments; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear wavy boundary.  (2 to 14 inches thick)
Cr--17 to 24 inches; soft weathered metasedimentary bedrock with visible secondary calcium carbonate as coatings on rock faces.  (0 to 15 inches thick)
R--24 inches; hard, fractured metasedimentary bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Fremont County, Colorado; about 1,600 feet west and 600 feet north of the southeast corner of Sec. 19, T. 49 N., R. 11 E.  U.S.G.S. Howard quad.; Lat. 38 degrees, 29 minutes, 34 seconds N., and Long. 105 degrees, 47 minutes, 40 seconds W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 43 to 47 degrees F.  Thickness of the mollic epipedon ranges from 4 to 12 inches.  Oe horizons are generally present, but are absent in some pedons.  A paralithic contact is at a depth of 6 to 20 inches.  A lithic contact is at a depth of 20 to 40 inches.  Depth to uniformly calcareous material ranges from 4 to 12 inches.
The A horizon has a hue of 7.5YR to 2.5Y, value of 3 through 5, 2 or 3 moist, and chroma of 2 or 3.  Reaction is neutral or slightly alkaline.
The Bk horizon has a hue of 7.5YR to 2.5Y, value of 5 through 7 dry, 4 to 6 moist, and chroma of 2 to 6.  Texture is very gravelly sandy loam, extremely gravelly sandy loam, or extremely gravelly loam.  Coarse fragment content ranges from 35 to 90 percent.  Content of fine or coarser sand is 35 percent or greater.  Clay content is 15 to 25 percent.  Reaction is moderately alkaline.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Ratake (CO) series.  Ratake soils lack a horizon of secondary calcium carbonate accumulation.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Casvare soils are on mountain slopes.  These soils formed in residuum from weathered granite, gneiss, and metavolcanic and metasedimentary rocks.  Slope ranges from 10 to 60 percent.  Elevation ranges from 7,200 to 8,500 feet.  The mean annual precipitation ranges from 12 to 16 inches.  Mean annual temperature ranges from 41 to 45 degrees F.  The frost-free season is about 90 to 115 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Teaspoon and Bronell soils.  The Teaspoon soil has an argillic horizon and also a lithic contact above a depth of 20 inches.  The Bronell soil lacks a paralithic or lithic contact above a depth of 40 inches.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; moderate and moderately rapid permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  This soil is used for woodland wildlife habitat, and livestock grazing.  Native vegetation is mainly pinyon pine and juniper woodland with a sparse understory of Scribner needlegrass, red threeawn, pricklypear, mountain mahogany, Gambel oak, mountain muhly, and blue grama.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountains and high foothill areas of central Colorado.  This series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Fremont County (Fremont County Area), Colorado, 1988.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Diagnostic features and horizons recognized in this soil include a mollic epipedon from 0 to 10 inches; a Bk horizon from 10 to 17 inches; a paralithic contact at 17 inches; and hard bedrock at 24 inches.  It has an ustic moisture regime and a frigid temperature regime.  Last updated by the state 8/95.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
